sen.j: 国衙（こくが）は、日本の律令制において国司が地方政治を遂行した役所が置かれていた区画を指す用語。
sen.e: Kokuga is a term for describing the land area in which a government office resides; this would be the location where a Kokushi (provincial governor) executed the local government functions of the Ritsuryo system (a centralized government system based on the Ritsuryo codes) in Japan.

Kokuga is a term for describing the section in which a government office, a Kokushi (provincial governor) executed the local government functions of the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in Japan, used to be located.
sen.cmt: land area→section, resides→be located として、文の構成を少し修正しました。
sen.e: Kokuga is a term for describing the section in which a government office, a Kokushi (provincial governor) executed the local government functions of the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in Japan, used to be located.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 平安時代頃までに、国司の役所そのもの（国庁という）を国衙と呼んだり、国司の行政・司法機構を国衙と呼ぶことが一般的となった。
sen.e: Leading up to the Heian period (794-1185) a government office of the Kokushi [it is called Kokucho (local government)] was called Kokuga; the Administration and Judiciary structures of the Kokushi were generally called Kokuga.

Leading up to the Heian period, it was generalized that a government office of the Kokushi (called Kokucho [local government]) itself was called Kokuga and the Administration and Judiciary structures of the Kokushi were called Kokuga.
sen.cmt: (794-1185)を除き、括弧を修正、it was..that～として文をまとめました。
sen.e: Leading up to the Heian period, it was generalized that a government office of the Kokushi (called Kokucho [local government]) itself was called Kokuga and the Administration and Judiciary structures of the Kokushi were called Kokuga.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: また、国衙に勤務する官人・役人を「国衙」と呼んだ例も見られる。
sen.e: In some cases a ranking government official (lower or middle ranked) and other government officials, those who served the Kokuga, were called "Kokuga."
In some cases, a ranking government official (lower or middle ranked) and other government officials, those who served the Kokuga, were called 'Kokuga.'
sen.cmt: クオーテーションマークを修正しました。
sen.e: In some cases, a ranking government official (lower or middle ranked) and other government officials, those who served the Kokuga, were called 'Kokuga.'
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 国衙を中心として営まれた都市域を国府といった。
sen.e: A kokufu (provincial capital) was the direct result of a city regions' development rising outward and encompassing the Kokuga, located in its center core.
The city area where developed around Kokuga was called kokufu (provincial capital).
sen.cmt: city region→city area とし、文全体を修正しました。
sen.e: The city area where developed around Kokuga was called kokufu (provincial capital).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

tit.e: Ruins and land-use plans (or zoning plans)
Ruins and land-use plans (or zoning plans)
Ruins and land-use plans (or zoning plans)

sen.j: 主な国衙遺跡には、周防国衙（防府市）、常陸国衙（石岡市）、近江国衙（大津市）、土佐国衙（香美市）などがある。
sen.e: The main Kokuga Ruins are the cities of: Suo Kokuga (Hofu City), Hitachi Kokuga (Ishioka City), Omi (Otsu City), and Tosa Kokuga (Kami City).
The main ruins of Kokuga include Suo Kokuga (Hofu City), Hitachi Kokuga (Ishioka City), Omi Kokuga (Otsu City), and Tosa Kokuga (Kami City).
sen.cmt: Kokuga Ruins→ruins of Kokuga, are the cities of→include, Omi→Omi Kokuga に修正しました。
sen.e: The main ruins of Kokuga include Suo Kokuga (Hofu City), Hitachi Kokuga (Ishioka City), Omi Kokuga (Otsu City), and Tosa Kokuga (Kami City).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: これらの国衙遺跡から、各国の国衙区画プランにいくつかの共通点があることが判っている。
sen.e: Archeologists and other experts studied these Kokuga Ruins mentioned previously and found that each land-use plan for the Kokuga shared several common points.
These ruins of Kokuga showed that each land-use plan for the Kokuga shared several common points.
sen.cmt: Archeologists～studied, previously and found を除き、Kokuga Ruins→ruins of Kokuga, mentioned→showed と修正しました。
sen.e: These ruins of Kokuga showed that each land-use plan for the Kokuga shared several common points.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 国衙の中心的な施設として、国庁正殿が置かれた。
sen.e: A central facility of the Kokuga, Kokucho Seiden (main palace for the local government) was established.
As a central facility of the Kokuga, Kokucho Seiden (main palace for the local government) was established.
sen.cmt: As を加えました。
sen.e: As a central facility of the Kokuga, Kokucho Seiden (main palace for the local government) was established.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 正殿の前後には、前殿・後殿が設置されることもあった。
sen.e: In some of the Kokuga locations there was a mae dono (front palace) and a ushiro dono (rear palace) situated at the front and the back of a seiden (main palace).
In some of the Kokuga locations there were a mae dono (front palace) and a ushiro dono (rear palace) situated at the front and the back of a seiden (main palace).
sen.cmt: was→were
sen.e: In some of the Kokuga locations there were a mae dono (front palace) and a ushiro dono (rear palace) situated at the front and the back of a seiden (main palace).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 正殿は北寄り正面に南向きに建てられることが多かった。
sen.e: Often a seiden (main palace) was built at the front, facing the north side, and a seiden was positioned facing the south side of the premises.
Seiden was often built at the front to the north side, facing south of the premises.
sen.cmt: Often a seiden→Seiden was often とし、(main palace)、 and a seiden was positioned を除きました。
sen.e: Seiden was often built at the front to the north side, facing south of the premises.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: それで、脇殿は東西に置かれ、それぞれ東脇殿・西脇殿と呼ばれていた。
sen.e: Then, a wakiden (hall standing nearby main hall) was usually situated facing to the east and facing to the west of the seiden; these wakidens were called the higashiwakiden (palace located on the east side) and the nishiwakiden (palace located on the west side).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Then, wakiden (hall standing nearby main hall) were situated on the east and the west side of the seiden and each of the wakiden were called the higashiwakiden (palace located on the east side) and the nishiwakiden (palace located on the west side).
sen.cmt: usually～to→on, facing to the west→and, these wakidens→and each of～ としました。
sen.e: Then, wakiden (hall standing nearby main hall) were situated on the east and the west side of the seiden and each of the wakiden were called the higashiwakiden (palace located on the east side) and the nishiwakiden (palace located on the west side).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 中央を広場とした。
sen.e: The center premises of the Kokuga were to be maintained as open space.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The center of the Kokuga was maintained as open space.
sen.cmt: premisesを除き、were to be→was としました。
sen.e: The center of the Kokuga was maintained as open space.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 建物配置は左右対称であった。
sen.e: All of the buildings on the premise of the Kokuga were situated in a symmetrical manner.
All of the buildings on the premise of the Kokuga were situated in a symmetrical manner.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: All of the buildings on the premise of the Kokuga were situated in a symmetrical manner.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: これらの官衙群は築地塀・掘立柱塀で囲まれた区域内に整然と配置されていた。
sen.e: These kanga (government office) buildings were neatly situated within the boundary area on the premises of Kokuga, and surrounded by tsuijibei (a mud wall with a roof) and hottate bashira bei (a wall with pillars embedded directly in the ground).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: These kanga (government office) buildings were neatly situated within the area surrounded by tsuijibei (a mud wall with a roof) and hottate bashira bei (a wall with pillars embedded directly in the ground).
sen.cmt: boundary, on the premises of Kokuga, and を除きました。
sen.e: These kanga (government office) buildings were neatly situated within the area surrounded by tsuijibei (a mud wall with a roof) and hottate bashira bei (a wall with pillars embedded directly in the ground).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: この国衙域はおよそ数十メートル-100メートル前後四方に区画されていることが多かった。
sen.e: This Kokuga area was often divided into sections: a unit was assembled in multiple meters of ten to a hundred, comprising the front, the rear, and all four sides.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This Kokuga area was often divided into sections in multiple meters of ten to a hundred square.
sen.cmt: comprising～sides.→square とし、: a unit was assembled を除きました。
sen.e: This Kokuga area was often divided into sections in multiple meters of ten to a hundred square.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 敷地の周囲は堀立柱の板塀や築地塀や溝で区画されていた。
sen.e: A building site of Kokuga was surrounded by a wooden fence, hottate bashira (pillars embedded directly into the ground) and the tsuiji, a ditch; a Kokuga was divided into sections through the placement of these walls and ditches.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: A building site of Kokuga was surrounded by a wooden fence and tsuijibei (a mud wall with a roof) made of hottate bashira (pillars embedded directly into the ground) and a ditch.
sen.cmt: 「築地塀」を用語集の通りに修正しました。文全体の構成を修正、a Kokuga was～の部分を除きました。
sen.e: A building site of Kokuga was surrounded by a wooden fence and tsuijibei (a mud wall with a roof) made of hottate bashira (pillars embedded directly into the ground) and a ditch.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 南に門を置く。
sen.e: The gate of the Kokuga was built on the south side of the property.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The gate was built on the south side.
sen.cmt: of the Kokuga, of the property を除きました。
sen.e: The gate was built on the south side.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 建物構造は掘立柱や礎石建ちの二種。
sen.e: Building structures of the Kokuga were restricted to two types of architectural methods: Hottate bashira and soseki dachi (a structure built with a stone foundation).
Building structures of the Kokuga were restricted to two types of architectural methods: Hottate bashira and soseki dachi (a structure built with a stone foundation).
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: Building structures of the Kokuga were restricted to two types of architectural methods: Hottate bashira and soseki dachi (a structure built with a stone foundation).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: ただし、国庁正殿や国衙域の規模は、各国ごと、時代ごとに異なっていた。
sen.e: However, the scale of a Kokucho Seiden and a Kokuga's area would vary by province and time period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, the scale of a Kokucho Seiden and a Kokuga area varied with province and time period.
sen.cmt: Kokuga's→Kokuga, would vary by→varied with に修正しました。
sen.e: However, the scale of a Kokucho Seiden and a Kokuga area varied with province and time period.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: だから、各国衙区画プランを比較すると共通点よりむしろ差異が目立つ。
sen.e: Thus, there were more differing points than common points, when comparing the land-use plan of the Kokuga with other province land-use plans.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Thus, there were more different points than common points when comparing each of the land-use plans of the Kokuga.
sen.cmt: differing→differentに修正, with other～を除き、each of～ としました。
sen.e: Thus, there were more different points than common points when comparing each of the land-use plans of the Kokuga.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 国庁の周囲には、事務消耗品・備品や武器を製作する工房や食事のための厨屋など（これらを曹司という）が配置されていた。
sen.e: Around the Kokucho (local government), there were several subsections developed to compliment its function: Workshops for making office stationery and expendable supplies, equipment, and weapons: Kuriya (kitchen) for dining, and another functional place [This place was called a zoshi (a room in the Imperial court especially made for ladies of the court)].
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Around the Kokucho, there were workshops for making office stationery and expendable supplies, equipment and weapons and Kuriya (kitchen) for dining and other functional places (this place was called a zoshi [a room in the Imperial court especially made for ladies of the court]).
sen.cmt: 初出でないので (local government)を除き、 several～functionを除いてand で繋げ、括弧や大文字、コンマ等を修正しました。
sen.e: Around the Kokucho, there were workshops for making office stationery and expendable supplies, equipment and weapons and Kuriya (kitchen) for dining and other functional places (this place was called a zoshi [a room in the Imperial court especially made for ladies of the court]).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 他、国司の生活の場である国司館、租税を収蔵する正倉などが配置されていた。
sen.e: In addition, there were other buildings; the kokushi -kan (house where a provincial governor lives) was a living place for a kokushi (provincial governor); and a shoso (public repository) was for the keeping of collected land taxes.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In addition, there were other buildings called kokushi -kan where was a house of a provincial governor and a shoso (public repository) which was for keeping collected land taxes.
sen.cmt: buildings: →called とし文を繋げ、文全体を修正しました。
sen.e: In addition, there were other buildings called kokushi -kan where was a house of a provincial governor and a shoso (public repository) which was for keeping collected land taxes.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: これら建築群の配置態様は、各国によって全く異なっている。
sen.e: The design arrangement system for the positioning of these interior architectural buildings in the Kokuga, differed by province.
The layout of these architectural buildings completely differed from each province.
sen.cmt: design～positioning→layout, by→from each とし、completely を加えました。
sen.e: The layout of these architectural buildings completely differed from each province.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 最初期の国衙は、律令制構築段階の7世紀後期に登場したと考えられている。
sen.e: Historians and experts believed that the earliest type of Kokuga appeared during the development stage of the Ritsuryo system, established in the late seventh century.
It is believed that the earliest type of Kokuga appeared during the development stage of the Ritsuryo system which established in the late seventh century.
sen.cmt: Historians and experts→It isとし、which を加えました。
sen.e: It is believed that the earliest type of Kokuga appeared during the development stage of the Ritsuryo system which established in the late seventh century.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: しかし、この当時は地方政治制度が十分に確立していなかった。
sen.e: However, in this time period, the Japanese local political systems were not fully developed.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, in those days, the local political systems were not fully developed.
sen.cmt: this time period→those days とし、Japanese を除きました。
sen.e: However, in those days, the local political systems were not fully developed.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: だから、後に見るほど確固とした国衙が成立したわけではなかった。
sen.e: Therefore, the Japanese government didn't establish a Kokuga as the determinant political function; the Kokuga establishment would later evolve into a more solidified system.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, Kokuga had not been established firmly as it can be seen later.
sen.cmt: 原文に無い語句が多く見られるため、文全体を修正しました。
sen.e: Therefore, Kokuga had not been established firmly as it can be seen later.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 8世紀前期から中期にかけての時期、国衙は安定的に営まれるようになる。
sen.e: During this time period, from early to middle eighth century, the Kokuga was conducted in a stable manner.
From early to middle eighth century, Kokuga was conducted in a stable manner.
sen.cmt: During this time period, the を除きました。
sen.e: From early to middle eighth century, Kokuga was conducted in a stable manner.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: この時期が国衙の成立期だとされている。
sen.e: Therefore, historians and experts believed that the Kokuga's formation was during this time period.
Therefore, it is believed that Kokuga was formed during this period.
sen.cmt: historians and experts→it is, Kokuga's formation→Kokuga was formed, this time→this, としました。
sen.e: Therefore, it is believed that Kokuga was formed during this period.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 国衙には、律令の規定に基づいて守・介・掾・目の国司四等官と書記官である史生が勤務した。
sen.e: Under regulations of the Ritsuryo codes, the Kokuga employed the kokushi shitokan (four officials of the provincial governor) as follows: Kami (director of the provincial governors): Suke (vice governor of provincial offices, the second ranking government official): Jo (facilities manager, secretary of provincial offices, the third ranking government official): Sakan (clerk of provincial offices, the fourth ranking government official); the Kokuga also employed a secretary who worked as a Shisho (a clerk, a person doing miscellaneous duties on documents).

Under regulations of the Ritsuryo codes, the Kokuga employed the kokushi shitokan (four officials of the provincial governor) as follows: Kami (director of the provincial governors): Suke (vice governor of provincial offices, the second ranking government official): Jo (facilities manager, secretary of provincial offices, the third ranking government official): Sakan (clerk of provincial offices, the fourth ranking government official) and a secretary called Shisho (a clerk, a person doing miscellaneous duties on documents).
sen.cmt: the Kokuga also employed, who worked as を除きました。
sen.e: Under regulations of the Ritsuryo codes, the Kokuga employed the kokushi shitokan (four officials of the provincial governor) as follows: Kami (director of the provincial governors): Suke (vice governor of provincial offices, the second ranking government official): Jo (facilities manager, secretary of provincial offices, the third ranking government official): Sakan (clerk of provincial offices, the fourth ranking government official) and a secretary called Shisho (a clerk, a person doing miscellaneous duties on documents).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: この他の国衙職員としては、国博士・国医師・国師といった専門職員や雑徭によって徴発された徭丁らがいた。
sen.e: As for the other employees, the Kokuga employed the following specialists: Kunihakase (teacher of Japanese classical literature), Kuniishi (local governmental doctor), Kokushi (the most reverend priest), and then the Kokuga employed a Yotei (a mandatory laborer) who was requisitioned by the zoyo (irregular corvee)

As for the other employees, Kokuga employed specialists such as Kunihakase (teacher of Japanese classical literature), Kuniishi (local governmental doctor) and Kokushi (the most reverend priest) and a Yotei (a mandatory laborer) who was requisitioned by the zoyo (irregular corvee).
sen.cmt: the, and, ピリオド等を修正しました。
sen.e: As for the other employees, Kokuga employed specialists such as Kunihakase (teacher of Japanese classical literature), Kuniishi (local governmental doctor) and Kokushi (the most reverend priest) and a Yotei (a mandatory laborer) who was requisitioned by the zoyo (irregular corvee).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 合計すると小国では数十人、大国では数百人とかなりの規模の人数が勤務していた。
sen.e: The total number of workers in these small provinces ranged from more than ten to less than one hundred. A Taikoku (major provinces) employed a substantial body of workers, several hundred people.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The total number of workers in small provinces came to dozens of people and in major provinces came to a considerable workers such as several hundred people.
sen.cmt: 二文に分かれていたので一文に纏め、全体を修正しました。
sen.e: The total number of workers in small provinces came to dozens of people and in major provinces came to a considerable workers such as several hundred people.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: そして、国衙を中心に都市的な領域が形成されていた。
sen.e: These same workers resided outside the Kokuga's center, evolving this area into what would eventually become cities.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: And the city-like territory was formed around Kokuga.
sen.cmt: 全体を修正しました。
sen.e: And the city-like territory was formed around Kokuga.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 9世紀頃から律令法制と社会実情が次第に乖離していき、同世紀末には律令規定に基づく地方統治が困難となってきた。
sen.e: In ninth century, the Ritsuryo system gradually detached itself from the actual social situation; gradually and eventually governmental administrations reign over the locals became more difficult.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In ninth century, the Ritsuryo system gradually detached itself from the actual social situation and governmental administrations reign over the locals became more difficult.
sen.cmt: gradually and eventually を除き、and で繋げました。
sen.e: In ninth century, the Ritsuryo system gradually detached itself from the actual social situation and governmental administrations reign over the locals became more difficult.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 10世紀前期、朝廷は統治権限を大幅に国司へ移譲する国制改革を行った（これにより成立した体制を王朝国家体制という）。
sen.e: Then, in the early part of tenth century, the Imperial Court executed a national governmental systems reform; the government transferred the greatest authority over administration to the Kokushi (This system established by this reform was called the system of the dynasty state.).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Then, in the early part of tenth century, the Imperial Court executed a national governmental systems reform that transferred the greatest authority over administration to Kokushi (This system established by this reform was called the system of the dynasty state).
sen.cmt: 余分なスペース、ピリオド等を修正、; the government→that として繋げました。
sen.e: Then, in the early part of tenth century, the Imperial Court executed a national governmental systems reform that transferred the greatest authority over administration to Kokushi (This system established by this reform was called the system of the dynasty state).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 国司は大幅に増えた権限に対応するため、国衙機構の強化に努めるようになっていった。
sen.e: In order to cope with the massively increased power, the Kokushi attempted to strengthen the structure of Kokuga.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In order to cope with the massively increased power, the Kokushi attempted to strengthen the structure of Kokuga.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: In order to cope with the massively increased power, the Kokushi attempted to strengthen the structure of Kokuga.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 租税収取を所管する部署（税所・田所・大帳所・出納所など）や、軍事を所管する部署（健児所・検非違使所・厩所など）、所務・雑務を所管する部署（政所・調所・細工所・膳所など）を国衙に整備していった。
sen.e: So, the Kokushi modified the Kokuga, establishing several departments: A department to control the collection of taxes [zeisho (tax office), tadokoro, daichosho (the major accounting and reporting office), suitodokoro (teller's office), and others]: A department in control of military affairs [kondeidokoro (military office), kebiishi dokoro (police and judicial office), umayadokoro (stable office), and others]: A department in control of the shomu (land management) and routine tasks [Mandokoro, choso (checking office), saikudokoro (tooling office), zendokoro (food office), and others].
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: So, the Kokushi modified the Kokuga, establishing several departments such as a department to control the collection of taxes (zeisho [tax office], tadokoro, daichosho [the major accounting and reporting office], suitodokoro [teller's office], and others), a department in control of military affairs (kondeidokoro [military office], kebiishi dokoro [police and judicial office], umayadokoro [stable office], and others), a department in control of the shomu (land management) and routine tasks (mandokoro, choso [checking office], saikudokoro [tooling office], zendokoro [food office], and others).
sen.cmt: such asを加え文を繋げ、括弧を修正しました。
sen.e: So, the Kokushi modified the Kokuga, establishing several departments such as a department to control the collection of taxes (zeisho [tax office], tadokoro, daichosho [the major accounting and reporting office], suitodokoro [teller's office], and others), a department in control of military affairs (kondeidokoro [military office], kebiishi dokoro [police and judicial office], umayadokoro [stable office], and others), a department in control of the shomu (land management) and routine tasks (mandokoro, choso [checking office], saikudokoro [tooling office], zendokoro [food office], and others).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 同じ頃、国司が任国へ赴任せず（遙任という）、目代という代理人兼監督者を現地派遣していた。
sen.e: During this same period, a Kokushi did not leave for the assigned province [this was called yonin (remote appointments)] and instead sent out a mokudai (deputy kokushi, or a deputy provincial governor), who was a deputy and also director to the assigned province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In those days, a Kokushi did not leave for the assigned province (called yonin [remote appointments]) and sent out a mokudai (deputy kokushi, or a deputy provincial governor) instead, who was a deputy and also director to the assigned province.
sen.cmt: During this same period→In those days とし、instead の位置、括弧を修正しました。
sen.e: In those days, a Kokushi did not leave for the assigned province (called yonin [remote appointments]) and sent out a mokudai (deputy kokushi, or a deputy provincial governor) instead, who was a deputy and also director to the assigned province.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 現地の有力者や官人（在庁官人という）に国衙政治を任せるケースが増えていた。
sen.e: Then, the Kokushi put a local influential person and government official in charge of the Kokuga [Zaichokanjin (the local officials in Heian and Kamakura periods)], this type of practice steadily increased among the kokushi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Then, the cases that Kokushi put a local influential person and government official in charge of Kokuga (Zaichokanjin [the local officials in Heian and Kamakura periods]) had been steadily increased.
sen.cmt: The cases～increased の形にして、括弧を修正しました。
sen.e: Then, the cases that Kokushi put a local influential person and government official in charge of Kokuga (Zaichokanjin [the local officials in Heian and Kamakura periods]) had been steadily increased.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 11世紀・12世紀になると、国衙政治の実務は事実上在庁官人が担うようになっており、受領国司は在庁官人の力なしに国内統治を果たすことはできなかった。
sen.e: In reality, during the eleventh and twelfth centurys, the Zaichokanjin controlled Kokuga politics, and the zuryo Kokushi (provincial governor) would not be able to execute governing duty of the province without this Zaichokanjin's political power.

In reality, during the eleventh and twelfth centurys, the Zaichokanjin controlled Kokuga politics and Zuryo (the head of the provincial governors) Kokushi could not execute governing duty of the province without Zaichokanjin's political power.
sen.cmt: 「受領」を用語集の通りに修正、would not be able to→could に修正しました。
sen.e: In reality, during the eleventh and twelfth centurys, the Zaichokanjin controlled Kokuga politics and Zuryo (the head of the provincial governors) Kokushi could not execute governing duty of the province without Zaichokanjin's political power.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 11世紀中期頃から荘園の増加が著しくなり、従来、国衙が支配していた公田が次第に減少していった。
sen.e: Around the middle of eleventh century, the numbers of Shoen (a manor in medieval Japan, a private estate) increased dramatically, and subsequently the Koden (territories administered directly by a ruler), which was used by the Kokuga to govern, decreased gradually.

From the middle of eleventh century, a number of Shoen (manor in medieval Japan) increased remarkably, and subsequently Koden (territories administered directly by a ruler) which was originally controlled by Kokuga decreased gradually.
sen.cmt: Around→From, the numbers→a number, dramatically→remarkably, used→controlled に修正、「荘園」を用語集の通りに修正、originally を加えました。
sen.e: From the middle of eleventh century, a number of Shoen (manor in medieval Japan) increased remarkably, and subsequently Koden (territories administered directly by a ruler) which was originally controlled by Kokuga decreased gradually.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 国衙はこれに対抗するため、支配する公田を領域的にまとめた。
sen.e: In order to confront to this problem, decreased territory of the Koden and the increasing territory of Shoen; the Kokuga arranged and united all of the controlled territory of a koden domain into one unit.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In order to confront to this problem, Kokuga arranged and united all of the controlled territory of a koden domain into one unit.
sen.cmt: decreased～Shoen;の部分を除きました。
sen.e: In order to confront to this problem, Kokuga arranged and united all of the controlled territory of a koden domain into one unit.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: これを、郡・保・郷・条などの支配単位に再編成した。
sen.e: Then, the Kokuga reorganized the rules of the koden implementing the following system: Koori (district, a unit of 2-20, 50-home neighborhoods or townships, in the Ritsuryo period), Ho (district, a unit of 5-home neighborhoods or townships, in the Ritsuryo period), Go [district, a unit of 50-home townships (comprised of 2-3 neighborhoods), in the Ritsuryo period], and Jo (a unit or a system to divide lands in the Ritsuryo period).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Then, Kokuga reorganized the rules of the koden implementing the following system: Kori (district, a unit of 2-20, 50-home neighborhoods or townships, in the Ritsuryo period), Ho (district, a unit of 5-home neighborhoods or townships, in the Ritsuryo period), Go (district, a unit of 50-home townships [comprised of 2-3 neighborhoods], in the Ritsuryo period), and Jo (a unit or a system to divide lands in the Ritsuryo period).
sen.cmt: Koori→Kori として、括弧を修正しました。
sen.e: Then, Kokuga reorganized the rules of the koden implementing the following system: Kori (district, a unit of 2-20, 50-home neighborhoods or townships, in the Ritsuryo period), Ho (district, a unit of 5-home neighborhoods or townships, in the Ritsuryo period), Go (district, a unit of 50-home townships [comprised of 2-3 neighborhoods], in the Ritsuryo period), and Jo (a unit or a system to divide lands in the Ritsuryo period).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: こうして国衙は自らの支配域を領域化することに成功した。
sen.e: The Kokuga succeeded in the territorialization of areas within its control.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Then, Kokuga succeeded to territorialized their own controlled territory.
sen.cmt: Thenを加え、in the territorialization→to territorialized, areas within its control→their own controlled territory としました。
sen.e: Then, Kokuga succeeded to territorialized their own controlled territory.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: こうして成立した国衙の支配域を国衙領という。
sen.e: These newly established controlled areas of the Kokuga were called Kokugaryo (territories governed by provincial government office).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: These newly established controlled areas of the Kokuga were called Kokugaryo (territories governed by provincial government office).
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: These newly established controlled areas of the Kokuga were called Kokugaryo (territories governed by provincial government office).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 鎌倉時代になると、幕府は各国へ守護を設置した。
sen.e: In the Kamakura period, Kamakura Bakufu established the new position of Shugo (provincial constable, a provincial military governor) and assigned a Shugo to each province.
In the Kamakura period, bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) established Shugo (provincial constable) in each province.
sen.cmt: 「幕府」「守護」を用語集の通りに修正、new position, assigned を除きました。
sen.e: In the Kamakura period, bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) established Shugo (provincial constable) in each province.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 守護は検断権のみが認められていたのであり、国衙の統治権を侵害する存在ではなかった。
sen.e: This Shugo had an approved power only applicable in the right to judge criminal cases and would not disrupt the sovereignty of the Kokuga.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Shugo had an approved power only applicable in the right to judge criminal cases and did not disturb the sovereignty of the Kokuga.
sen.cmt: This を除き、would→did, disrupt→disturb としました。
sen.e: Shugo had an approved power only applicable in the right to judge criminal cases and did not disturb the sovereignty of the Kokuga.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: が、守護が所在した守護所はしばしば国衙の近隣に営まれ、国衙・守護所両者の機能が次第に一体化する傾向が見られ始めた。
sen.e: However, the shugosho (provincial administration) where Shugo resided was often built near-by the Kokuga property; so, the Kokuga and Shugo began to develop a tendency in the gradual integration of their functions.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, the shugosho (provincial administration) where Shugo resided was often built near-by the Kokuga property; so, the Kokuga and Shugo began to develop a tendency in the gradual integration of their functions.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: However, the shugosho (provincial administration) where Shugo resided was often built near-by the Kokuga property; so, the Kokuga and Shugo began to develop a tendency in the gradual integration of their functions.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 室町時代の守護は検断権だけでなく更に強力な統治権限が認められた。
sen.e: In the Muromachi Period, the Shugo authority was increased from the right to judge criminal cases to the inclusion over its administration.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the Muromachi Period, Shugo was given not only the right to judge criminal cases but also more powerful authority of administration.
sen.cmt: not only..but also～の形にしました。
sen.e: In the Muromachi Period, Shugo was given not only the right to judge criminal cases but also more powerful authority of administration.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: そのため、守護は積極的に国衙の統治権限を蚕食していった。
sen.e: Thus, it was at this point that the Shugo aggressively encroached upon the authority in the administration of the Kokuga.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Thus, Shugo had aggressively encroached on the authority in the administration of the Kokuga.
sen.cmt: it was～that the の部分を除きました。
sen.e: Thus, Shugo had aggressively encroached on the authority in the administration of the Kokuga.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: その結果、室町前期のうちに国衙機構は守護所に取り込まれ、ほとんどの国衙は実質的に消滅した。
sen.e: The resulting change, during the early Muromachi Period, from the political structure of the Kokugas' being acquired by the Shugo; and it was instrumental in the functional disappearance of the Kokuga.
As a result, during the early Muromachi Period, the political structure of the Kokuga was absorbed by Shugosho and practically most of Kokuga disappered.
sen.cmt: The resulting change→As a result, from～以降の文を修正しました。
sen.e: As a result, during the early Muromachi Period, the political structure of the Kokuga was absorbed by Shugosho and practically most of Kokuga disappered.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 国衙が地名として残存している例はそれほど多くないが、防府市国衙（周防国衙跡）が比較的有名である。
sen.e: There are few remaining cases of Kokuga named sites; of which Kokuga, Hofu City (Suo Kokuga Ruins) is relatively famous.
Although there are few cases remaining Kokuga as the place name, Hofu City Kokuga (Suo Kokuga ruin) is relatively famous.
sen.cmt: Althoughを加え、remaining～sites→cases～name, Ruins→ruin としました。
sen.e: Although there are few cases remaining Kokuga as the place name, Hofu City Kokuga (Suo Kokuga ruin) is relatively famous.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: そのほかの地名としては以下の例がある。
sen.e: There are other places named Kokuga, for example:
There are other places named Kokuga, for example:
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: There are other places named Kokuga, for example:
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 山梨県笛吹市御坂町国衙（甲斐国衙跡）
sen.e: Misakacho Kokuga, Fuefuki City, Yamanashi Prefecture
Misakacho Kokuga, Fuefuki City, Yamanashi Prefecture (Kai Kokuga ruin)
sen.cmt: 括弧内の訳漏れ。
sen.e: Misakacho Kokuga, Fuefuki City, Yamanashi Prefecture (Kai Kokuga ruin)
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 群馬県安中市松井田町国衙（上野国衙跡）
sen.e: Matsuidamachi Kokuga, Annaka City, Gunma Prefecture
Matsuidamachi Kokuga, Annaka City, Gunma Prefecture (Kozuke Kokuga ruin)
sen.cmt: 括弧内の訳漏れ。
sen.e: Matsuidamachi Kokuga, Annaka City, Gunma Prefecture (Kozuke Kokuga ruin)
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 兵庫県南あわじ市神代國衙（淡路国衙跡）
sen.e: Zindaikokuga Minamiawaji City, Hyogo Prefecture
Zindaikokuga Minamiawaji City, Hyogo Prefecture (Awaji Kokuga ruin)
sen.cmt: 括弧内の訳漏れ。
sen.e: Zindaikokuga Minamiawaji City, Hyogo Prefecture (Awaji Kokuga ruin)
sen.cmt: 修正なし
